model_input:
[Task Description]
You will be given DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY.
Your job is to judge if MEMORY contains helpful past information for a language model, representing Parent, to generate a proper next response based on DIALOGUE CONTEXT.

If the DIALOUGE CONTEXT does not require the model to utilize past information for response generation, say "N/A".
Say "Yes" if MEMORY contains such helpful information and say "No" if it dose not.
Provide a brief explanation for your judgement.

[Format Regulation]
Generate your output below OUTPUT using the following format:
Brief explanation: your explanation
Judgement: "Yes", "No", or "N/A"

[Task]
DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
You know, I always valued being a good listener. It's an important skill to have in life.
Yeah, I think listening is really important too. I always feel heard when I talk to you.
That's great to hear. I think listening is especially important when people are going through a tough time. It can make a big difference to feel like someone is really hearing you.
Did you feel like that when you were in detention? Like nobody was really listening to you?
Yeah, it was tough. I felt so alone and scared, and I didn't know if anyone would understand what I was going through. But eventually, I found someone who was willing to listen and it made all the difference.
I'm glad you found someone to talk to. You know, I remember when we watched the sunrise together a few weeks ago. That was really special.
It was. I love being able to appreciate the beauty of nature. And you know, having my own place to live in the suburbs makes it even easier to do things like that.
Yeah, your house is really nice. You've always been good at taking care of yourself.

[MEMORY]
Related Evidences: (1) {'Related Topics': 'Juvenile Detention Experience', 'Related Summaries': 'Parent shares their experience in juvenile detention with Child and reflects on finding hope in difficult situations.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Parent: Hi, kiddo. How are you doing? ### Child: I'm doing okay, I guess. How are you? ### Parent: I'm not doing very well. I was taken to juvenile detention today. ### Child: What?! Why? What happened? ### Parent: Well, I got into some trouble with the law. I feel scared and upset right now. ### Child: I'm sorry to hear that. Do you know how long you will have to stay there? ### Parent: Not yet. That's something I'm trying to figure out. ### Child: Is there anything I can do to help? ### Parent: Just knowing that you're thinking of me and supporting me means a lot. Thank you. ### Child: Of course, Dad. I love you. ### Parent: I love you too, kiddo. And I'm sorry for any pain that my actions may have caused you. ### Child: It's okay, Dad. Everyone makes mistakes. We'll get through this together. ### Parent: That means a lot to me, son. Thank you. ### Parent: I remember waking up early one morning while I was in juvenile detention. I couldn't see the sunrise from my cell, but I still felt hopeful that things would get better. ### Child: That must have been tough, not having the freedom to just go outside and watch the sunrise. ### Parent: It was. But I learned to appreciate the small moments and find hope even in the darkest of situations. ### Child: That's really inspiring, Parent. Did you ever get to see the sunrise when you got out of detention? ### Parent: I did. One morning, I woke up early and went outside to watch the sunrise. It was a reminder to me that there is always a new day and a chance to start fresh. ### Child: That's so beautiful. Maybe we can wake up early one day and watch the sunrise together.' }(2) {'Related Topics': 'Rebuilding Life and Independence', 'Related Summaries': 'Parent talks about making changes, having their own place, and striving for independence while cherishing moments with Child.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Parent: I'm so glad I have my own place now. It may not be much, but it's mine. ### Child: I love it here too, it feels like home. ### Parent: I know I made some mistakes in the past, but I'm trying to turn my life around. ### Child: I'm proud of you, Dad. It takes a lot of courage to admit when you're wrong and make changes. ### Parent: Thank you, kiddo. I just want to make sure you have a safe and stable environment to grow up in. ### Child: I appreciate that. I love spending time with you here, especially when we have breakfast together in the backyard. ### Parent: Yes, those mornings watching the sunrise are some of my favorite memories with you. ### Child: I remember the first time we did that. You woke me up so early, but it was worth it. The sunrise was beautiful. ### Parent: I'm glad you enjoyed it. And speaking of the sunrise, have you been up early enough lately to see it? ### Child: No, not really. But maybe we can do it again one weekend soon. ### Parent: That sounds like a great plan. We can have breakfast outside again and enjoy the peace and quiet before the neighborhood wakes up. ### Child: I'm looking forward to it, Dad. I love spending time with you.' }
```
